title-group.article-title: Radiofrequency-Assisted Liver Resection With a Comb-Shaped Bipolar Device Versus Clamp Crushing
title-group.subtitle: A Clinical Study

author-notes.corresp: Gennaro Galizia, Second University of Naples School of Medicine, “F. Magrassi-A. Lanzara” Department of Clinical and Experimental Medicine and Surgery, c/o II Policlinico, Edificio 17, Via Pansini 5, 80131 Naples, Italy Email: gennaro.galizia@unina2.it

abstract.p: Background. In liver surgery, clamp-crushing (CC) procedure has been shown to be the most efficient system for liver transection. Recently, it has been suggested that radiofrequency-assisted liver resection (RFALR) may be more advantageous, but sufficient evidence has yet to be accumulated. Method. The control group was constituted by 32 patients undergoing CC liver transection. The study group included 13 patients undergoing RFALR with a new fully automated radiofrequency generator supplying a comb-shaped bipolar multielectrode device. Results. RFALR allowed a faster hepatic transection and reduced both surgical time and intraoperative blood loss. RFALR was the only independent prognostic indicator of bleeding during liver transection. No significant liver damage and postoperative complications, particularly biliary leakage and stenosis, were experienced in the RFALR group. Conclusion. Compared with the CC procedure, this bipolar device was shown to be safe and effective in liver resections, allowing a very clean surgical field without increase of postoperative complications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Liver resection represents the most common treatment option for both primary and metastatic hepatic tumors.1,2 Improvements in surgical techniques and increased knowledge of liver anatomy and physiology have significantly decreased postoperative mortality and morbidity.3,4 However, hepatic surgery remains a very demanding procedure requiring a skilful approach and adequate preparation.5 Both excessive blood loss and blood transfusion requirement have been shown to be associated with a significant increase in postoperative complications and poor long-term outcome.2,6-8 In addition, inadequate sealing of bile ducts and wide residual of necrotic tissue may cause a disappointing high rate of complications.9,10 Inflow and outflow vascular control, namely hilum dissection/ligation or Pringle’s maneuver and hepatic vein clampage, as well as use of hypotensive anesthetics able to lower central venous pressure have been advocated to decrease intraoperative blood loss.11 However, the crucial point is represented by how to split the liver parenchyma maintaining a sufficiently clean surgical field and optimizing identification of vascular and biliary structures.5 Since the first description of the finger fracture technique (digitoclasy),12 subsequently improved through the use of surgical instruments such as small Kelly (clamp crushing),13,14 several methods have been proposed for a safer liver resection, including the use of ultrasonic dissector (CUSA, Tyco Healthcare, Mansfield, MA),15 Hydrojet (Erbe, Tubingen, Germany),16 harmonic scalpel (Ultracision, Ethicon Endo-surgery, Cincinnati, OH),17 dissecting sealer (TissueLink, Dover, NH),18 LigaSure (Covidien, Boulder, CO),19 and radiofrequency generator (radiofrequency-assisted liver resection [RFALR]).1,3,5,20-22 There have been several studies to date, including randomized controlled trials, comparing these techniques with contrasting results, so that the optimal method of liver parenchyma division remains to be established.18,19,23

Since the landmark description by Habib and associates,3 it has been suggested that RFALR, which induces necrotic clotting of the defined resection plane, may be performed in a clean surgical field with significant reduction in intraoperative blood loss.24-26 However, some authors argued that this technique could cause both a higher rate of bile leak and abdominal abscess formation, damage large vessels, and, finally, sacrifice parenchymal tissue that is usually spared using other resectional procedures.1,3,5,21,27

In this controlled, nonrandomized cohort study, we used a new bipolar high-frequency generator supplying a comb-shaped multielectrode device to perform liver resections. Our study end points were the following: (a) the reliability of the method with respect to a clean surgical field with minimal blood loss, (b) the safety of the procedure (ie, RFALR-related complications), and (c) the incidence of postoperative complications (particularly, biliary leakage, abscess formation, and liver failure rates).

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: At our institution, no particular device was used to split the hepatic parenchyma until December 2009, and liver resections were performed by Kelly clamp-crushing (CC) method. From January to October 2010, in a prospective fashion, RFALR was performed in 13 consecutive patients with primary or metastatic hepatic tumors (group 1). Thirty-two liver tumor patients undergoing hepatic resection between January 2007 and December 2009, in whom no device had been used, constituted the control group (group 2 or CC group).

All patients underwent careful preoperative assessment, including laboratory tests, spiral computed tomography (CT) scanning or magnetic resonance imaging, and CT-positron emission tomography to rule out extrahepatic tumor deposits.

The following parameters were recorded in all patients: age, sex, performance status according to ECOG scale, reason for surgery (primary or metastatic liver tumor), previous abdominal surgery, total bilirubin and creatinin serum levels (mg/dL), prothrombin activity (international normalized ratio), platelet count, Child-Pugh grade,28 MELD score (model for end-stage liver disease),1 underlying liver disease (presence of cirrhosis), preoperative chemotherapy, and tumor size. All patients gave their informed consent, and the study was approved by the ethics committee at the Department of Clinical and Experimental Medicine and Surgery of the Second University of Naples.

sec.title: Intraoperative Procedures
sec.p: Conventional open surgery with appropriate subcostal incision was used, and the liver mobilized according to the site and size of the lesion(s). An intraoperative ultrasonogram was always performed to plan the resection and reveal undetected lesions, and the hepatic hilum encircled for eventual Pringle’s maneuver. In the CC group, a line was traced with the diathermy scalpel on the liver capsule to mark the edges of the liver resection, and the parenchyma was progressively divided clipping or tying all blood vessels and biliary structures. On the contrary, in RFALR group, 2 lines (inner and outer, the latter approximately 0.5 cm apart from the inner) were traced according to bimanual palpation and ultrasound. This is a crucial point of this technique because after radiofrequency is used, the liver parenchyma becomes hardened and hyperechogenic, thus limiting the identification of the lesion.3,25 When the tumor was located close (1 cm or less) to the hepatic hilum or inferior vena cava, these structures were preventively separated from the lesion to avoid thermal injuries. The coagulative necrosis was produced by a comb-shaped bipolar multielectrode device (four or six 1.5 mm diameter needles with a 7.5 cm or 10 cm long active end) connected to a 300-kHz generator (Surtron SB, LED SpA, Aprilia (LT), Italy), producing up to 325 W of radiofrequency power (Figure 1). The system has a constant incremental voltage, and the total tension to apply is adjustable in 9 levels; with level 3 of tension, a coagulation line of 6 to 8 mm of amplitude in the hepatic parenchyma is obtained. Increasing the level of the tension diminishes the amplitude of the coagulation line, and vice versa. Of note, regulation of the level of tension according to the thickness of the parenchyma is not necessary, and the unit is fully automated.

caption.p: Surtron SB, LED SpA, Aprilia (LT), Italy, connected to a comb-shaped bipolar multielectrode device (6 needles with a 7.5 cm long active end)

sec.p: The application method entailed performing 2 parallel lines of coagulation so that a coagulation amplitude was produced of approximately 12 to 16 mm. The 2 parallel applications achieved some overlap assuring completion of the coagulation. The length of the electrodes allowed obtaining a plane of necrotic clotting from the upper to the inferior surface of the liver, thus avoiding further insertions of the needles. However, for a more safe and accurate procedure, each line of coagulation was obtained with up to 3 consecutive radiofrequency applications progressively withdrawing the needles. Finally, the liver parenchyma was divided using the scalpel along a plane situated midway between the inner and outer lines leaving in situ 6 to 8 mm of coagulated tissue. A part of our own experience is available in a video at the following Internet address: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QynFdJswJe8. In each group, extent (minor or major [defining as major a resection of 3 or more Couinaud’s segments])29 and type of resection (single or multiple), use of inflow vascular control, operation and liver transection time, transection area (obtained by adding the area in cm2 of each transection plane), transection speed (calculated as transection area divided by transection time [cm2/min]), intraoperative blood loss (total and during liver transection), blood loss for transection area (calculated as blood loss during liver transection divided by transection area [mL/cm2]), and blood transfusion requirement were carefully recorded.

sec.title: Postoperative Outcome
sec.p: In all patients postoperative liver functions were assessed by daily measurements of hepatic tests until hospital discharge. Biliary leakage was diagnosed when the abdominal drain could not be removed on day 14 after surgery, and either percutaneous drainage or endoscopic retrograde sphincterotomy or relaparotomy was required. Need for blood transfusion or relaparotomy to perform hemostasis defined postoperative bleeding. Abdominal fluid collection, with signs of sepsis requiring percutaneous drainage or relaparotomy, identified abscess formation. Time to discharge, mortality rate, and pathologic margin involvement were also recorded.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was carried out using the SPSS statistical package (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). In all analyses, the significance level was specified as P < .05. The equality of group means and comparisons between proportions were analyzed using unpaired Student’s t test and χ2 test, respectively. Multivariate analysis was performed using a logistic regression model to estimate the relative risk (hazard ratio) of 2 liver resection methods on blood loss during liver transection, which was categorized according to the median value in all patients (200 mL), after controlling for 6 potential confounders.18,19

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The characteristics of the series are listed in Table 1. The 2 groups matched well; particularly, no significant differences were shown in serum levels of liver function tests, score systems, underlying liver disease, and reason for surgery. The CC group suffered from a slight, but not statistically significant, higher rate of major and single hepatectomies (Table 2). In addition, transection area was not different between the 2 groups, thus showing that the demanded surgical engagement was identical in both groups. However, RFALR was associated with significant greater transection speed (P = .015) and shorter liver transection (P = .023) and operation time (P = .019). Blood loss was significantly reduced by using RFALR both during liver transection (P = .029) and for transection area (P = .005). Accordingly, total amount of intraoperative blood loss was significantly different between the 2 groups (P = .016). Although not significant, probably because of the small numbers of the series, need for intraoperative blood transfusion was 7.7% in the RFALR group and 28% in the CC group. Ultimately, inflow vascular occlusion was necessary in 34% of the CC group and never in the RFALR group (P = .040). With regard to RFALR, no bleeding was seen on introduction of the needles. On removal, bleeding sometimes occurred from 1 or more holes but was easily controlled by pressure. Division of the liver parenchyma by using the scalpel was always simple and safe in a very clean surgical field; small incidental bleeding was controlled with diathermy; major vessels (including right or left Glissonian sheath and hepatic vein) were easily identified in the desiccated liver parenchyma and tied for a safest procedure.

sec.p: On multivariate analysis, the transection method was shown to be an independent prognostic factor related to blood loss during liver transection. The CC method had a 9.31 (95% confidence interval: 1.34-64.4) higher relative risk of increased blood loss than the RFALR technique (Table 3). Reduced platelet count and presence of cirrhosis were clearly related to an increased risk of blood loss, even if they failed to reach significant values. On the contrary, extent and type of resection, reason for surgery, and prothrombin activity were not independent covariates.

sec.p: There were no significant differences in the postoperative outcome between the 2 groups (Table 4). The serum liver test peaks were quite similar. However, in the RFALR group no major complications were encountered, excluding 1 case of liver failure successfully treated with medical therapy. On the contrary, in the CC group, 3 cases of biliary leakage, 2 postoperative bleeding, and 1 abscess formation occurred. There was no mortality in group 1; in the CC group a patient died of liver failure. The higher rate of postoperative complications caused a significant longer hospital stay in the CC group. Surgical margins were free of tumor in all patients except 1 case in each group (7.7% in group 1 and 6.3% in group 2). To date, no signs or symptoms of biliary stenosis have been experienced in both groups.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Despite considerable decrease in perioperative mortality and morbidity rate, liver resection still remains a difficult and dangerous procedure.28,30 Since increase in intraoperative blood loss and blood transfusion requirement have been shown to be independent predictors of higher complication and adverse outcome rates,2,6-8,30,31 minimizing these factors is currently considered a crucial issue to improve results after liver resection.1,4,32 Accordingly, the method used for liver transection, which has been considered an important factor influencing both the cleansing of the surgical field and intraoperative blood loss, is to date under careful evaluation.1,10,19,22 In several studies, the standard CC method, compared with CUSA, Hydrojet, and dissecting sealer, has been shown to be the most effective in terms of resection time, blood loss, blood transfusion requirement, and costs.1,5,10,18,33-38 A recent meta-analysis by Pamecha et al,23 including 7 randomized trials and a total of 556 patients, confirmed previous single reports suggesting that the CC method should represent the reference standard against which new methods should be compared.23 However, in this meta-analysis only 1 study included the use of a monopolar radiofrequency generator,5 and the results clearly showed that, without any inflow vascular control, blood loss was significantly reduced by using CUSA or radiofrequency.23 Thus, sufficient evidence has yet to be gained to identify the most suitable method, and liver surgeons still select the method of liver transection according to their own preferences.19

Habib’s group first applied radiofrequency to perform liver resection by using a monopolar device.3 The innovative step with this technique was that, in contrast with liver tumoral tissue, coagulation of normal liver parenchyma was very fast, with operative time, blood loss, and transfusion requirement significantly reduced.25,39 However, major drawbacks with a monopolar device were progressively identified: the system required grounding pads, thus carrying risk of skin burn and cardiac arrhythmias; the probe was time consuming having to be deployed many times to cover the designed resection plane; sealing of large vessels was frequently inadequate; and, finally, an excessive and uncontrolled amount of energy was delivered to the surrounding tissues.25,26 Especially the last one, potentially capable of producing an excessive amount of dead tissue at the cut edge of the liver, was supposed to be related with a higher rate of postoperative biliary leakage and abscess formation, thus suggesting caution in the use of RFALR.1,3,5,21,27 For these reasons, some authors have recently developed square shaped or linear multielectrode devices delivering bipolar current, which have shown promising results.22,25,26,32 However, these investigations have been judged inconclusive,23 as they had not been compared with CC method,22,25,32 and at times the precoagulated liver was split using the CUSA with the equipment requiring continuous power setting.26

In this study, we used a new fully automated radiofrequency generator and compared the results with the CC method. We avoided use of other devices to exclude confusing factors. The comb-shaped bipolar probe, delivering controlled radiofrequency energy among the electrodes, avoided overcoagulation of the surrounding tissue and sealed even major biliary and blood vessels, allowing the splitting of the liver parenchyma with scalpel in a very clean surgical field. Compared with the CC method, RFALR had higher transection speed, thus reducing both liver transection and operation time. Significant reduction of blood loss avoided requirement of inflow vascular control, which was never needed in patients undergoing RFALR. Although it has been widely accepted that the liver may withstand warm ischemia and reperfusion injury,40,41 inflow vascular control can result in hemodynamic changes and liver damage, especially in cirrhotic, after chemotherapy, and fatty livers, thus predisposing to postoperative liver failure.22,26,32,36 Therefore, in addition to hemorrhage reduction, RFALR had the potential of decreasing ischemic injury to the liver by reducing the need for vascular occlusion. Of note, although the 2 groups did not show any difference with respect to the extent and type of liver resection, the RFALR group was subjected to a nonnegligible fewer major and more multiple hepatectomies. It may suggest, as already noted,32 that this method allows to perform more nonanatomical resections, thus sparing liver parenchyma, which may be particularly advantageous in patients requiring further hepatic surgery for cancer recurrence.25

There is no general agreement as to which factor should be considered to evaluate the effects of a method during liver resection.19 To date, total intraoperative blood loss, transection time, and transection speed have been chosen, but all these factors may be affected by other variables, such as patients’ characteristics, anatomical variations, and surgical skillfulness.18,19,23,34,37 Since the primary end point of the current study was to assess the reliability of the RFALR to allow a clean surgical field, blood loss during liver transection was chosen as a dependent factor. After controlling for 6 potential confounders, the transection method was shown to be the only independent prognostic indicator of bleeding during liver transection, and RFALR patients had a 9-fold decreased risk of blood loss when compared with CC patients.

Contrary to previous experiences,5,21 RFALR was not associated with a worrying increase of serum levels of postoperative liver function tests, thus suggesting no significant liver damage during surgery.32 In addition, RFALR patients did not experience biliary leakage and abscess formation, thus supporting the notion that this technique does not leave behind an excessive amount of necrotic liver tissue. Therefore, warning against the use of radiofrequency energy to perform liver resection may seem no longer justifiable by using such a bipolar device.27 To date, despite a short follow-up time, no RFALR patient suffered from biliary stenosis, which was considered a potential catastrophic event related to the conduction of radiofrequency energy to the main bile ducts. Indeed, these latter, in contrast to blood vessels, are not immune to heat injury.5,42 Clearly, a careful technique, including separation of hilar structures from the tumor, and use of a bipolar device may help avoid this complication.

In conclusion, this comb-shaped bipolar multielectrode device supplied by a fully automated radiofrequency generator has been shown to be safe and effective in liver resections. Compared with the CC method, RFALR allowed to have a very clean surgical field, reduced both intraoperative blood loss and resection time, and did not increase the rate of postoperative complications. One indisputable disadvantage was represented by the high cost (about €1500) of each disposable probe, while the CC method entailed no additional expenses. However, this problem might assume secondary importance, considering that RFALR shortened operation time and significantly reduced hospital stay.
